articles.headline: In Britain, Austerity Collides With Pension System
articles.snippet: The desires of the British prime minister to cut the budget deficit are running up against a situation created over decades: the large number of public entitlements.
articles.abstract: The desires of the British prime minister to cut the budget deficit are running up against a situation created over decades: the large number of public entitlements.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — It may be the age of austerity for many in Britain. For a former doctor, Geoffrey Lipman, it is anything but.

articles.headline: Obama’s Journey to Tougher Tack on a Rising China
articles.snippet: In the presidential campaign, China has become a focal point encompassing both security and economic concerns and highlighting the nations’ complex, tense relationship.
articles.abstract: In the presidential campaign, China has become a focal point encompassing both security and economic concerns and highlighting the nations’ complex, tense relationship.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama’s patience with China had been fraying for months, and by November 2010 he was fed up. Meeting with President Hu Jintao in Seoul, South Korea, Mr. Obama warned that if China did not do more to curb North Korea’s bellicose behavior, he would have to take steps to shield the United States from the threat of a nuclear missile attack from the North.

articles.headline: Circuit Court Needs to Let the S.E.C. Do Its Job
articles.snippet: In the area of regulatory law, the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia is controlled by judicial activists who seem willing to negate regulations they do not like.
articles.abstract: In the area of regulatory law, the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia is controlled by judicial activists who seem willing to negate regulations they do not like.
articles.lead_paragraph: The second-most important court in the United States has three vacancies, one of which was created in 2005. It may yet be the institution that dooms many or even most of the Dodd-Frank financial reforms that Congress passed in 2010 and that regulatory agencies have been struggling to put in place since then.

articles.headline: Wal-Mart Is Deleting the Kindle From Stores
articles.snippet: Retailers have been worried that displaying the new Kindles will encourage customers to browse in stores and then buy from online competitors instead, analysts said.
articles.abstract: Retailers have been worried that displaying the new Kindles will encourage customers to browse in stores and then buy from online competitors instead, analysts said.
articles.lead_paragraph: Wal-Mart Stores, the nation’s largest retailer, said Thursday it was dropping Amazon’s Kindle tablets and e-readers, a sign of how seriously it views Amazon as a competitor in the consumer goods market.
articles.byline: By Stephanie Clifford and Julie Bosman

articles.headline: Europe Said to Be Close to Approval of EMI Deal
articles.snippet: European regulators are set to approve a reduced version of the Universal Music Group’s $1.9 billion takeover of EMI Music, people involved in the talks said.
articles.abstract: European regulators are set to approve a reduced version of the Universal Music Group’s $1.9 billion takeover of EMI Music, people involved in the talks said.
articles.lead_paragraph: European regulators are set on Friday to approve a reduced version of the Universal Music Group’s $1.9 billion takeover of EMI Music, allowing Universal to expand its dominance as the world’s largest music company but significantly paring down its ambitions, according to several people involved in the talks.

articles.headline: Behind the Scenes, Some Lawmakers Lobby to Change the Volcker Rule
articles.snippet: In public letters and closed-door meetings, more than 100 lawmakers have appealed to the Federal Reserve and other authorities over the Volcker Rule, records show.
articles.abstract: In public letters and closed-door meetings, more than 100 lawmakers have appealed to the Federal Reserve and other authorities over the Volcker Rule, records show.
articles.lead_paragraph: As regulators put the finishing touches on new rules for Wall Street, they remain entangled in a partisan fight over the overhaul.

articles.headline: After Attack in Libya, an Ambush Struck Rescuers
articles.snippet: The assault on American diplomatic facilities in Benghazi was moblike at first but became a sophisticated onslaught.
articles.abstract: The assault on American diplomatic facilities in Benghazi was moblike at first but became a sophisticated onslaught.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The survivors of the assault on the American Mission in Benghazi, Libya, thought they were safe. They had retreated to a villa not far from the main building where the surprise attack had occurred, and a State Department team had arrived to evacuate them. The eruption of violence had ended, and now they were surrounded by friendly Libyan brigades in what seemed to be a dark, uneasy calm.
articles.byline: By Steven Lee Myers, Michael S. Schmidt and Suliman Ali Zway

articles.headline: Before Debates, Romney Faces a Daunting Path
articles.snippet: There are 46 days left in this presidential race for Mitt Romney to change the dynamic of a campaign that by many indicators is tilting against him.
articles.abstract: There are 46 days left in this presidential race for Mitt Romney to change the dynamic of a campaign that by many indicators is tilting against him.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — There are seven days until early voting begins in Iowa, less than two weeks until the first debate and 46 days left in the race for Mitt Romney to change the dynamic of a campaign that by many indicators is tilting against him.
articles.byline: By Jeff Zeleny and Jim Rutenberg

articles.headline: Life Spans Shrink for Least-Educated Whites in the U.S.
articles.snippet: A long rise in Americans’ life spans has reversed itself for white people who lack high school diplomas, an increasingly troubled group that has lost four years of life expectancy since 1990.
articles.abstract: A long rise in Americans’ life spans has reversed itself for white people who lack high school diplomas, an increasingly troubled group that has lost four years of life expectancy since 1990.
articles.lead_paragraph: For generations of Americans, it was a given that children would live longer than their parents. But there is now mounting evidence that this enduring trend has reversed itself for the country’s least-educated whites, an increasingly troubled group whose life expectancy has fallen by four years since 1990.

articles.headline: IPhone 5 Fever? Don’t Count Samsung Out
articles.snippet: It doesn’t have the media coverage or the passionate fan base, but the giant South Korean manufacturer has built an impressive lead in global mobile phone sales.
articles.abstract: It doesn’t have the media coverage or the passionate fan base, but the giant South Korean manufacturer has built an impressive lead in global mobile phone sales.
articles.lead_paragraph: By many measures, Samsung Electronics should be on the ropes. Last month, it lost an important patent battle with its rival Apple after a jury in the United States ruled that Samsung had illegally copied aspects of Apple’s groundbreaking iPhone. Apple introduced its newest model, the iPhone 5, to enthusiastic reviews and a worldwide consumer frenzy, with customers lining up to buy the new model days before it arrived in stores on Friday. This week, Apple shares hit a record high and cracked the $700 threshold.
